newsitem.title: USA: Orange County assistant treasurer found guilty.
newsitem.headline: Orange County assistant treasurer found guilty.

text.p: A jury on Friday found former Orange County, Calif., assistant treasurer Matthew Raabe guilty of felony charges stemming from the largest municipal bankruptcy in U.S. history.
The jury of six men and six women convicted Raabe, a central figure in the county's bankruptcy crisis, on all five counts, including the misappropriation of public funds and lying to investors.
Raabe, 41, showed little emotion while the verdict was read out. His wife burst into tears.
Raabe was told to post $25,000 bail. If he failed to, he would immediately be taken into custody, court officials said.

Raabe chose not to testify on his own behalf during the five-week trial in state Superior Court in Santa Ana, the Orange County seat. He now faces as many as 13 years in prison and a $10 million fine.
The prosecution said the verdict, announced on the third day of deliberations, was a major victory.

"The evidence was extremely strong (that) Raabe was the mastermind of the whole operation," Orange County Assistant District Attorney Jan Nolan told reporters. "There was just no doubt how the jury was supposed to come back and I'm very, very glad that they came back with this verdict."
The defense said the verdict was a shock.
"It's a huge disappointment," defense attorney Gary Pohlson said. "I'm shocked that they found this man guilty, especially in such a short period of time."
Pohlson added, "The evidence was clear that this was a good man who worked hard for the county."
Orange County filed for bankruptcy in December 1994 after sustaining losses of more than $1.6 billion on risky investments. The county emerged from bankruptcy last June.
Raabe was indicted by a county grand jury in May 1995.
He faced five felony counts, which included the misappropriation of public funds, making false statements in the sale of securities and failure to transfer public funds.

County prosecutors alleged that Raabe helped divert nearly $90 million in interest earnings owed to cities, schools and special districts that invested in the county-run investment pool before the county descended into bankruptcy.
One juror told reporters after the verdict was read that panel members felt sympathy for Raabe but found the evidence too strong to ignore.
A hearing was set for Monday to set a date for Raabe's sentencing.

Nolan said Friday's verdict marked "the end of a chapter" in the county's bankruptcy saga. Raabe's trial could be the last brought by the county district attorney as part of its investigation of the crisis.
"He (Raabe) has now been forced to take responsibility," Nolan said. "But I don't know if anything can help the county put the bankruptcy behind it."
Raabe was one of several Orange County officials to face charges after the bankruptcy.

In April 1995, former Orange County Treasurer Robert Citron, facing the same charges as Raabe, pleaded guilty. A judge last November ordered him to spend a year in jail and pay a $100,000 fine, but Citron was later assigned to a community work program instead of jail.
Last October, a judge sentenced former Orange County budget director Ronald Rubino to probation for his role in the investment crisis.
A state appeals court last November dismissed charges against two Orange County supervisors accused of misconduct in connection with the bankruptcy.
Then in March an appeals court disqualified Orange County's district attorney from prosecuting the county auditor-controller on accusations stemming from the crisis.
